questions.text:
Which of the following muscles are supplied by the lateral plantar nerve?

1. Abductor hallucis

2. Flexor digitorum accesorius

3. Flexor hallucis brevis

4. First lumbrical

5. First interossei
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

2 and 5 

The muscles innervated by the lateral plantar nerve are the flexor digitorum accessorius (quadratus) and the first dorsal interosseous (interossei) muscle. The sole of the foot is supplied by both the medial and lateral plantar nerves, which are branches of the tibial nerve

questions.text: Which ligament connects medial cuneiform to the base of the 2nd metatarsal?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Lisfranc

The Lisfranc ligament connects the medial cuneiform to the base of the 2nd metatarsal. Lisfranc ligament is a cuneometatarsal interosseous ligament. It is the strongest ligament among the three cuneometatarsal interosseous ligaments. It passes from the lateral surface of the medial cuneiform to the adjacent angle of the second metatarsal bone.

questions.text: Which is not a branch of facial artery in the face?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Mental artery

Mental artery is not a branch of the facial artery but the branch of the maxillary artery in the face. The first part of the maxillary artery gives rise to the mental artery as a terminal branch of the inferior alveolar artery.

questions.text:
Arrange in sequence the structures involved in the direct pathway:

1. Striatum

2. Globus pallidus

3. Substantia nigra

4. Thalamus

5. Cortex
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

5,1,2,3,4

The sequence of structures involved in the direct pathway is cortex > striatum > globus pallidus > substantia nigra > thalamus.

questions.text:
Arrange lung hilar structures from anterior to posterior.

1. Primary bronchus

2. Bronchial artery

3. Pulmonary vein

4. Pulmonary artery
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

3,4,1,2

questions.text: Which of the following structures passing via jugular foramen has a separate canal?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Glossopharyngeal nerve  

The glossopharyngeal nerve passing through the jugular foramen has a separate canal. The jugular foramen is formed by the occipital bone and the petrous part of the temporal bone. The spinal accessory nerve and vagus nerve also pass through this foramen

questions.text: The rupture of penile urethra does not cause extravasation of blood into which of the following spaces?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Ischiorectal fossa 

Rupture of the penile urethra causes extravasation of blood into the superficial perineal pouch, scrotum, penis, and then up to the lower anterior abdominal wall. The superficial perineal pouch is a compartment of the perineum enclosed by the membranous layer of the perineal fascia that surrounds the scrotum or labia and penis or clitoris.

questions.text:
Arrange the structures of the cubital fossa in sequence from medial to lateral.

1. Median nerve

2. Radial nerve

3. Tendon of biceps brachii

4. Brachial artery
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

1,4,3,2

The structures are arranged in the cubital fossa from medial to lateral as follows:

Median nerve

Brachial artery

Tendon of biceps brachii

Radial nerve

choices.text: Fundus and body of Gall bladder

questions.text: Anterior relations of the third part of the duodenum are all except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

Fundus and body of Gall bladder 

Anterior relations of the third part of the duodenum include the Superior mesenteric vessels, the Root of the mesentery, and Loops of the jejunum.

questions.text:
Which of the following muscles form the pelvic diaphragm?

A. lliococcygeus

B. Pubococcygeus

C. Obturator internus

D. Deep transverse perineium
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

A,B 

lliococcygeus and pubococcygeus are parts of the pelvic diaphragm, which is also known as the levator ani.

questions.text: Which nerve is blocked when local anesthesia is given below the inguinal ligament during femoral vein catheterization?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Genitofemoral nerve 

Genitofemoral nerve is blocked when the local anesthetic is given below the inguinal ligament during femoral vein catheterization. The genitofemoral nerve originates from the L1 and L2 ventral rami. It divides into the genital and femoral branches after crossing behind the ureter.

questions.text:
Identify the incorrectly matched pairs of pharyngeal arch and its artery.

i. Ist arch - Maxillary artery

ii. 2nd arch - Hyoid and stapedial artery

iii. 3rd arch - Common carotid and proximal internal carotid artery

iv. 4th arch - Subclavian artery

v. 6th arch - Aorta on the left side
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

V

The 6th pharyngeal arch has its blood supply on the left side from the left pulmonary artery and ductus arteriosus, not from the aorta

questions.text: What is the root value of cremasteric reflex?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

L1,L2 

Cremasteric reflex is mediated by L1 and L2. In this reflex, there is ipsilateral elevation of the testicle following stroking of the medial thigh.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman was undergoing cholecystectomy. During the procedure, the resident accidentally advanced the scissors along the superior border of the epiploic foramen causing injury. Which of the following structures is likely to be injured?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Caudate lobe of liver 

The superior border of the epiploic foramen (foramen of Winslow) is formed by the caudate lobe of the liver. It is likely to be injured in this case. Epiploic foramen is a vertical slit of about 3 cm behind the free right border of the lesser omentum. It connects the lesser sac to the greater sac

choices.text: Present medial to white rami communicantes

questions.text: All of the following are true about grey rami communicantes except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Preganglionic

The grey rami communicantes are not preganglionic fibers. They are postganglionic fibers

questions.text: The talocalcaneonavicular joint is a which type of joint?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Ball and Socket 

The talocalcaneonavicular joint functions like a ball-and-socket joint. Its ball component is the rounded head of the talus, while the socket is formed by three structures: the posterior surface of the navicular, the anterior articular surface of the calcaneus, and the upper surface of the plantar calcaneonavicular (spring) ligament

questions.text:
Which of the following muscles are supplied by Superior Gluteal Nerve?

1. Gluteus Medius

2. Gluteus Minimus

3. Tensor fascia lata

4. Piriformis
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

1,2,3 

Gluteus Medius, Gluteus Minimus, and Tensor fascia lata are supplied by Superior Gluteal Nerve. Piriformis is supplied by the nerve to the piriformis

questions.text:
Arrange the following afferent columns in the floor of the fourth ventricle from medial to lateral.

1. General somatic

2. General visceral

3. Special somatic

4. Special visceral
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

2,4,1,3 

From medial to lateral, the afferent columns in the floor of the fourth ventricle are general visceral, special visceral, general somatic, special somatic.

questions.text:
Arrange the cells according to their positions from the basal layer towards the lumen in the seminiferous tubules.

1. Spermatogonia

2. Primary spermatocyte

3. Spermatid

4. Spermatozoa

5. Myoepithelial cell
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

5,1,2,3,4

From the basal layer towards the lumen in the seminiferous tubules, the cells are arranged in the order of:

Myoepithelial cells

Spermatogonia

Primary spermatocyte

Spermatid

questions.text: What represents the marked area in the given histology of lymph node?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

Mantle zone  

The area indicated in the image corresponds to the mantle zone of a lymph node. The lymph node contains a primary follicle, made up of small, resting lymphocytes, and a secondary follicle featuring a germinal center populated by antigen-stimulated B cells. The mantle zone forms as surrounding cells are displaced by the rapidly expanding germinal center. It contains predominantly quiescent B cells with condensed heterochromatic nuclei and minimal cytoplasm (which gives this region a deeply basophilic appearance on routine stains). The mantle also includes a few helper T cells, follicular dendritic cells, and macrophages.
